name: Gandule Rice
author: B. Mason
summary: A Puerto Rican dish with local Hawaiian flavor. Labor intensive, but also delicious. One ingredient, pigeon pea, is Native to Africa and is also called 'Congo pea' and 'no-eyed pea'; achiote seeds are slightly musky-flavored seeds of the annatto tree, available whole or ground in East Indian, Spanish and Latin American markets. Buy whole seeds when they're a rusty red color; brown seeds are old and flavorless. Achiote seeds are also called 'annatto' which, in its paste and powder form, is used in the United States to color butter, margarine, cheese and smoked fish.
ingredients: 15 ounces black olives, pitted and halved
directions: Heat 2 tablespoons of the oil in a large saucepan over medium high heat
Add pork and brown in oil
Meanwhile, place remaining oil in a small saucepan over medium heat and add achiote seeds
Heat until oil becomes very dark orange/red
Remove from heat and set aside
To the browned pork add the onion, cilantro, garlic, salt and pepper
Cook to reduce veggies, then add the tomato sauce, pigeon peas and olives
Strain achiote/oil mixture into pork mixture and stir together
Reduce heat to low and let simmer for 10 minutes
Add uncooked rice and water to pork mixture; stir well
Raise temperature to high, cover saucepan and bring all to a boil
Stir again, reduce heat to low and cover; let cook on low about 10 minutes
Remove cover, stir again, replace cover and cook another 10 minutes; stir again
Remove from heat and allow to stand 15 minutes
